posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: we have a through bore encoder on our climber and when we power on the robot at its lowest position the values are positive. But when it’s up during startup the values are negative? Why is this happening?

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
When the encoders are in relative mode they report the value relative to the starting position. Whatever position you start them in becomes 0. If you go up from there the value is positive, if you go down, it’s negative.

The other mode is absolute position but that only works if you have less than one full revolution on your encoder. With an elevator/climber, relative position is most likely the correct mode.

The solution is to either a) always physically reset the climber before powering on or b) add a button to reset the encoder and create a new zero after you lower the climber.

I think option a) is going to work best for most teams.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: the climber needs to be a absolute encoder. it does not go above one rotation. we have the encoder on the pivot shaft so it does not go above one rotation. and the value isnt 0 when we boot. its either ± 1 from the previous value

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
I don’t know about the WCP encoders offhand, but I know Rev’s through-bore encoders have a little switch that toggles them between relative and absolute. Perhaps WCP ’s through-bores have the same thing, and you need to set that. I have to admit, though, I’m having a hard time parsing this:

But when it’s up during startup the values are negative?

My interpretation of what you wrote:

If the climber is down at boot, you see a range of 0 (down) to N (up). If the climber is up at boot, you’re seeing a range of -N (down) to 0 (up)?

Is that correct?

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Yes, I feel like it’s the discontinuity point of that encoder. But I’m not sure how to fix this issue. We have had this same issue on both our end effector pivot and the climber

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
Ah! I’ll bet this is a code problem. By any chance, are your programmers grabbing a value from the encoder at startup, and assuming that’s the “down” position? If so, that’d explain why the zero point moves depending on where the climber is positioned at boot.

You may also be hitting the discontinuity point. If the shaft makes a full 360 degree rotation, you may just need to work around that. 1732’s prototype bot had this issue, and you just had to remember to flip the scoring mechanism around to the right spot before powering on the bot.
If you want the absolute position of the WCP throughbore encoder, you need encoder.getAbsolutePosition() instead of encoder.getPosition() or encoder.getPositionSinceBoot() .

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: We don’t do anything with the encoder values directly. we use it to set soft limits and that’s it. How do we determine the proper discontinuity point. Also we cant flip it to the right position on bootup because it is outside of frame and the climber gear ratio is too high to move by hand when powered on
